bibl.title: The Sixth Book of the Select Letters of Severus, Patriarch of Antioch in the Syriac Version of Athanasius of Nisibis
Translation, I.1 - II.3
To the Orthodox at Emesa

category.catDesc: Used to denote a date calculated by the editor from a regnal year or some other dating method given in the text.

revisionDesc.change: CHANGED: Add a human readable version or the tei:relation element in a tei:desc.

event.desc: Sometime between 519-520 Severus of Antioch sent a letter to Anonymi 3753 about the attempts of Gregory and Isaiah to falsely claim episcopal status. He refuted their claims with references to scripture, canon law, and the lifestyles of these men.

occupation.note: Gregory was a bishop of questionable legitimacy.
Isaiah was a bishop of questionable legitimacy.

event.desc: Sometime around 519-520 Gregory attempted to claim he had been legitimately ordained a bishop and claim episcopal authority in Antioch. He attempted to claim he held authority based on his ordination in Diocaesarea.
Sometime around 519-520 Isaiah attempted to claim he had been legitimately ordained a bishop and claim episcopal authority in Emesa.
Sometime around 519-520 Isaiah produced false canons in an attempt to claim that his ordination by one bishop was lawful.
Sometime before 519 Isaiah travelled to Egypt and Pamphylia seeking support for his claim to episcopal office.

relation.desc: Anonymous 3755 was the parent of Anonymous 3754.

event.desc: Sometime around 519-520 Isaiah attempted to demonstrate his sanctity in the city of Alexandria by raising Anonymous 3754 from the dead. He was unsuccessful and fled.

occupation.note: Epiphanius was the bishop of Magydum

relation.desc: Epiphanius had ecclesiastical authority over Isaiah.
Isaiah was an alledged follower of Montanus.
Isaiah was a follower of Mani.
Epiphanius and Eusebius had an intimate relationship.

event.desc: Severus buried Epiphanius in the monastery of Abba Peter the Iberian.

relation.desc: Anonymi 3756 were the children of Eusebius.

occupation.note: Paulinus was the bishop of Antioch
Evagrius was the bishop of Antioch

relation.desc: Anonymi 3757 ordained Flavian I of Antioch.

occupation.note: Flavian was the bishop of Antioch
Siricius was the bishop of Rome
Theophilus was the bishop of Alexandria
